And tokens are one of the things I'm
focusing on, which I think is very important,
because the timing is right for this.
So I'm going to talk about tokens, token standards,
and then what you can use tokens for.
I had an accident with my laptop last night.
We had some wine, so I spilled over it.
So I don't have my laptop with me anymore.

but it's not.

So what are tokens?
Why do we care about it?
There are several reasons why we want to use tokens.
And tokens are-- there are several ways to describe it.
You can describe tokens as assets, digital assets,
and so forth.
Personally, I like to use the words fungibles.
That's not a fungible.
That's a fungible.
But if you want to know what a fungible is,
it's something that's of the nature of kind
to be freely exchangeable, replaceable,
in whole, in part for any like nature of kind.
And fungibility is a property of a good commodity
whose individual units are capable of mutual substitution.
So that's just basically fancy speak for saying,
you can trade things around, and you
can measure the amount of units you have for something.
So when you think of tokens, people often
think that it's worth less play money.
But we use tokens in almost every facet of our lives.
We use tokens as coins, currencies.
We think about it as shares or equating things.
It can be prediction market outcomes.
It can be used in energy meters.
It represents energy hours, tickets, access tokens,
et cetera, et cetera.
So it can represent almost anything.
And the reason why this talk is important
at this point in time, because this
is the first thing that a lot of people
are going to use on a theorem, and have already
started using it in a theorem, is that we
need to find a way for these kind of token systems
to interoperate with each other, and then also
find a way for other daps to use these tokens
in their ecosystems.
So there's been a community effort,
mainly spirit by the foundation, to design some of these
standards so that these things can interoperate easily.
And the current ones are around tokens, registries,
data feeds, and forwarding contracts.
The most important one at this stage is tokens,
because that's the first one most people will use.
The standards are important.
Usually, standards are important.
But the reason why it's relatively more important
in a theorem's case is that when you deploy things,
it's more difficult to update it,
unless you bolt in these kind of features
to allow to change functionality in the future.
So if we assume we're going to have a token for-- which
is a share in a company that's going to last 150 years,
then this thing needs to be future-proof as possible.
So that's why these standards are important and why
we need to discuss this.
So one of the other problems with standards
is the standards are not easy.
This is a relevant SKCD comic that there
would be a situation where there are 14 competing standards.
And then someone says, that's ridiculous.
Why don't we just make one universal standard that
takes all use cases into account?
And what you end up with is just 15 competing standards.
Standards often develop like JavaScript
in a sense that all that you need to do
is to be in the right place at the right time.
The thing that gets the most adopted
is the standard that wins.
JavaScript was built to be used in the browser.
And before we knew it, it's used on hardware.
So it's literally just being in the right place at the right time
which standard is being used the most often.
You can discuss ad infinitum about what kind of things
should be in a standard.
But the one that will win at the end of the day
that will be used by most people is the one that
gets developed the most or deployed.
So with the MIST and Ethereum wallet recently launched,
you can issue and create tokens from there.
And everyone already needs to consider that.
There are a lot of people who have really started issuing tokens.
So what do the current token standards look like?
The only deal with transfers and approvals.
So transfer is how do you send tokens around?
And the approval system is the possibility
to give custodian access to other contracts and so forth.
It does not prescribe anything about how these tokens are created.
That's up to the token creator to decide.
And the general idea behind token systems
is that a token system lives in a specific address.
So these standards look as follows.
This was taken from the wiki page.
So everyone can go look at it.
So the first one is just a basic transfer.
You send your authorizes send your own money to someone else.
Then you have the transfer from, which is once you've
given someone else the possibility to send money
on your behalf, you specify who needs to send to whom.
Then a normal balance of API, which is obvious,
it returns the amount of tokens at a certain address.
Then these are the approval APIs, which
is the first one is the possibility
to give full custodian over your account.
So it's essentially saying this contract
can do whatever they want with my money.
You need to trust that contract's not
going to do something stupid or crazy.
Then you can remove or revoke that access.
And this, the unapproved, revokes both once of control
and full custodian control.
The once of control is where you essentially
is like a deposit type system where
you essentially give a contract the ability to once off up
to certain amount with draw money or extend money
from your account.
And then you have helper functions,
which you use to basically check if the account has access
to do certain things.

So it's essentially saying whoever
mince the contract is the owner of the initial balance.

a lot of these functionalities will be duplicated substantially.
